results.title: Respondent and operant behaviour (TEFC)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Behaviour Theory in Practice”.
Defines respondent and operant behaviour and shows laboratory experiments with mice, pigeons etc. illustrating biological and non- biological reinforcers and conditioning. Dogs and children demonstrate learned responses. Narrated by Jack K. Burton.
results.description:

results.title: Shaping various operants, various species (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Ellen Reese and Charter Oak Studios
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Behaviour Theory in Practice”.
Considers conditioning in six steps: shaping, adaptation, situation, motivation, operant level and final performance. These are illustrated by conditioned lever pressing by rats, high jumping by dogs, manipulation of a talking parrot and learning of handwriting by children.

results.title: Sequences of behavior (TEFC)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Behavior Theory in Practice”.
Shows procedure for conditioning homogeneous and heterogeneous behaviour chains. Demonstrates shaping of complex behaviour chains in pigeons, dogs in obedience trials, police dogs and guide dogs, showing practical application of laboratory findings

results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “BBC Television training film”
Illustrates what is involved in the production of television programs by following through all the stages of the making of an episode for the BBC Television series.

results.title: Videotape editing
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “BBC Television training film”
Describes techniques of editing in videotape recording for television. Commencing with part of a live studio program being recorded on tape and passing on to a detailed description of how video tape recording machines work.

results.title: Much Ado about Nothing
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “BBC Television Shakespeare Series”.
A comedy with two main plots. One concerns the love affair between Beatrice and Benedict, the other deals with the conspiracy against Claudio who is engaged to Beatrice’s gentle cousin, Hero. Don John, who hates Claudio stages a pretended assignation between Borachio, one of his followers, and Margaret, Hero’s maid, who is garbed as her mistress. Claudio, who witnesses the scene and suspects Hero’s virtue, rejects his bride at the altar, but the matter is finally cleared up, with the help of the good Friar Francis.
